text: Before starting a task, I notice whether my mind feels fast, foggy, wired, calm, or scattered.
When my attention drifts, I recognize what triggered the shift before I react.
I pause long enough to imagine the next three steps before I begin acting.
I start tasks without predicting what will happen next or considering the sequence.
When emotions spike quickly, I pause and breathe before my focus scatters.
I notice when my brain seeks stimulation and I choose to stay with the task anyway.
When my mind jumps between ideas, I see the pattern and guide it back to direction.
I switch tasks impulsively without recognizing that I'm seeking stimulation or escape.
I notice when boring tasks feel physically painful and I use short breaks to manage it.
When ideas flood in faster than I can organize them, I write them down to free my mind.
I recognize when my working memory feels overloaded and I offload thoughts to external systems.
I rely only on memory instead of using tools or systems to support my thinking.
When a task feels meaningless, I connect it to something that excites or challenges me.
I notice when my intensity needs direction instead of suppression.
When my thoughts move faster than the world around me, I slow down just enough to see the sequence.
I treat my fast brain as a personal failure instead of understanding it needs structure.
When I feel scattered, I step away briefly and reset my breathing before continuing.
I notice when my mind processes in a non-linear way and I adjust my approach accordingly.
When emotional spikes hit, I separate the stimulus from my action and give myself a micro-pause.
I expect myself to just try harder instead of building systems that match my brain's wiring.
